My father kept a second family in our basement. Last week, I found out the horrifying reason why. My dad has been feeding people in our basement for as long as I can remember. Every night at exactly 8:47, he would grab the leftover dinner, walk downstairs for 20 minutes, then come back up with an empty plate. I used to think this was completely normal until I realized how messed up it actually was. When I was 6, I asked my mom about the voices coming from downstairs. She just lit another cigarette and said, your father handles the basement handle upstairs. Her hands were shaking the whole time she said it. I could tell she was scared, but I didn't know why. The basement door was always locked with this huge deadbolt. I tried opening it once when I was eight, and my dad caught me. His face went completely white. He told me to never go down there because they weren't ready to meet me yet. But I could hear them. A little girl singing, A baby crying at three in the morning. Christmas was the weirdest time because my dad would bring two sets of presents. One pile for me and another armload that disappeared downstairs. I'd hear kids screaming with excitement while I opened my gifts alone upstairs. Mom would just chain smoke by the window, staring at nothing. When I turned 12, everything changed. The singing stopped. No more laughter, no more voices. Just Complete silence. But dad still brought food down every single night. He'd come back up faster, though, looking sick. Mom started drinking wine for breakfast. Convinced my best friend Trevor to sleep over that weekend. Maybe if someone else was there, dad would finally explain what was going on. But at 8:47, he grabbed the plate like always. Trevor followed me to the basement door. That's when we heard her. A woman's voice, desperate and hollow. Please let us out. Austin's getting older. He'll understand now. We've been good. We've been so good. Trevor's face went completely white. Dude, that's messed up. We should call someone. But dad was already coming back up. He saw us by the door and dropped the plate. It shattered everywhere. Boys, go to Austin's room now! That night, I heard my parents fighting for hours. Mom was sobbing, saying they couldn't keep doing this. Dad kept repeating, they need to stay down there. You know what happens if they don't. The next morning, Trevor's parents

I got upset at my wife's reason for marrying me. My wife Emma, is basically a robot when it comes to emotions. She's this data scientist who literally turns everything into spreadsheets and pros and cons lists. Like when we were picking what color to paint our bedroom, she made a whole Powerpoint about how blue affects sleep quality. I thought it was cute at first, you know, made me feel like she really thought things through. But Last Saturday, I asked her something that's been eating at me since. Why did you marry me? I was expecting some romantic answer about how much she loves me or how I make her laugh or whatever normal couple stuff. She looked at me dead serious and said, because you asked. I thought she was joking, so I laughed it off, but then I pushed a little more. Okay, but, like, what made you say yes, though? And this woman, my wife of three years, looks me straight in the eye and says, because I trust your judgment. I just stared at her. What the hell does that even mean? So I asked her to explain, and she went into full professor mode. She told me love isn't enough to marry someone. That when she was in college, she was head over heels for this guy named Tyler, who was basically a walking disaster. Good looking, charming, but had no goals, no t shirts and energy drinks. She said she would have Married him if he asked back then. Because she was young and

My siblings and I sat at dinner when our father smiled and asked, ready to compete for the upstairs bedroom? Again? I stared in shock. Again. I don't want to compete. Oh, sweetie, mom said, reaching across the table to pat my hand. The monthly room assignment builds character. Winners get the master suite. Losers get the basement. My younger brother, Marvin, pushed his food around his plate. My sister Bianca wouldn't even look up. We've been doing this for three months since we moved to this house. The basement had exposed pipes. heat. And spiders that dropped from the ceiling at night. Bianca won last month with her debate trophy. Dad continued, pulling out his notebook. So she keeps the room unless one of you beats her achievements this month. The chicken tasted like cardboard in my mouth. This is insane. Other families don't do this. Mom smile tightened. Other families raise weak children. We're raising winners. That night, Bianca came to my basement corner, where I'd hung sheets for privacy. I'm sorry, she whispered. Didn't wanna win, but sleeping down here made me sick last time. It's not your fault, I said, but the words felt hollow. Marvin had already stopped talking to both of us. The next morning, dad posted the point chart on the refrigerator. 10 points for A's, 20 for sports victories, 15 for volunteer hours, even five points for who said good morning first. I watched Marvin set his alarm for 4:00am. Just to beat us to the by week two, Bianca started hiding my homework. I found it crumpled in the trash after getting a zero. Marvin put a dead spider in my backpack during lunch, making me scream in front of everyone. We stopped eating together. Stop helping each other with assignments. Three kids living in the same house, acting like enemies. Look at that competitive spirit! Dad beamed one morning after Marvin and Bianca physically fought over who got to take out the trash for points. Mom took photos like it was something to be proud of. My grades started slipping from the stress. I couldn't sleep in the freezing basement constantly.

My neighbor kept stealing my packages, so I started ordering live bees. She opened one. For six months, Margaret from 4B took every package delivered to my door. Amazon, medications, even my mother's birthday gift. Had her on camera. But building management said it's a civil matter. And police said, talk to building management. So I got creative. Ordered 3,000 live honey bees from a bee farm. Completely legal. Left the package outside my door during my lunch break, when Margaret always struck. Twenty minutes later, screaming from the hallway. Margaret had opened the box in the elevator. Bees everywhere. The elevator automatically locked down. Safety feature during emergencies. Trapping her with thousands of confused bees for seven minutes. She wasn't allergic, just terrified and covered in bees. Building management suddenly cared about package theft. Elevator needed professional cleaning. $2,000. Three floors evacuated. Margaret sobbing in the lobby, bees in her hair. She tried to kill me. Margaret screamed at the police. You opened her package? The officer asked. It was delivered wrong. To her door? Yes, with her name, I thought. You thought what? That you'd steal it. I showed them six months of security footage I'd compiled. Margaret taking 47 packages, including my insulin, which she'd thrown away because it looked medical and gross. The officer looked at the bee invoice. Ma'am, she legally ordered live bees for her beekeeping hobby. You illegally opened her mail. That's a federal crime. What beekeeping hobby? I joined an urban beekeeping Group the week before had the membership card and everything. Margaret got charged with mail theft, 47 counts. The federal prosecutor was particularly interested in the insulin theft. Medical mail tampering is serious. She had to pay 4,008

I canceled our gender reveal party because I know my husband will be unhappy and possibly leave. So I'm 37 and pregnant with our second kid. My husband Jake is 43, and we already have a nine year old son named Connor. Jake absolutely worships this kid. I'm talking every new video game, basketball camp, you name it. They're like best friends. We had this whole gender reveal party planned for next week. Already paid for the venue at this fancy country club, put down deposits on a photographer, bought all these blue and pink decorations from target. The whole thing probably cost us, like $3,000. But here's the thing. Jake has been acting weird ever since I started showing. Not excited weird. More like stressed weird. He keeps making these comments about how it would be nice to have another boy and asking if I think the baby looks like a boy in the ultrasound pics. Last month, he actually said, and I quote, I just don't know what I'd do with a girl. When I asked him what he meant, he got all defensive and said he was just worried about teenage years and dating and stuff, but something felt off. We didn't do a gender reveal with Connor because Jake kept changing his mind about when he wanted to find out. We ended up learning it was a boy like three weeks before I gave birth, and Jake literally cried tears of joy in the doctor's office. So two weeks ago, Jake said maybe I should just go to my appointment alone and find out without him. He said he was too nervous and would rather wait for the party. I thought that was weird, but whatever. I went to Doctor Martinez's office by myself last Tuesday. She did the ultrasound and told me we're having a girl. I was honestly excited. I've been secretly hoping for a daughter. But when I got home,

I'm a teacher, and I've had the same student in my class for 10 years. He hasn't aged a single day. When I started teaching third grade at Rosewood Elementary, I thought I'd seen everything. But nothing prepared me for Ryan. He showed up on the second day of school clutching a class assignment sheet that said, Room 12, Mess Carter. Ryan Blackwood. I didn't remember his name on my roster, but kids get enrolled late all the time. Ryan was 8 years old. Blond hair, green eyes, small scar above his left eyebrow. Quiet kid who always sat in the back corner. Wore the same red hoodie every day. At the end of third grade, Ryan's parents apparently decided he needed to repeat the year. Academic struggles, they said. Weird, because Ryan was one of my brightest students. Fourth year of teaching, same thing. Ryan showed up again, clutching that assignment sheet. Same red hoodie, same corner seat. Still 8 years old. Fifth year, same Ryan. Same assignment sheet, same eight year old face. Sixth year, I started taking photos. Ryan in September looked identical to Ryan from five years ago. Same height, same baby teeth, same everything. Seventh year, I confronted the principal, showed her the photos. That's not the same child, she said. This year's student is Robert Blackwood, Ryan's younger brother. I looked at the photos again. Name on this year's assignment sheet had changed to Robert Blackwood in my hands. Eighth year, was Richard Blackwood. Same face, same scar. Same red hoodie that never faded. Ninth year brought Russell Blackwood. I started documenting everything. Every year, a new Blackwood boy who looked precisely like Ryan from five years ago. But in year 10, something changed. This year's assignment sheet read Ronald Blackwood. But when I looked at his face, his green eyes had no pupils, just solid green, like marbles. His skin had a waxy, artificial texture. During recess, he sat perfectly still for 30 minutes. Didn't move, didn't blink. Other kids played around him like he wasn't there. Ronald, are you okay? I asked. He turned his head toward me with a mechanical click. I'm fine, Miss Carter. His voice sounded hollow, like it was coming from inside a tunnel.

Waiting for my daughter to finish school, a parent turned to me and asked, did your ex husband have a beard? I giggled nervously. Um, yeah, why? No, no, no, no, no, she suddenly screamed while walking as far away from me as possible. I just laughed because moms can be so weird sometimes. But the next day, my daughter came home from school crying. Mommy, Leah said her mom said she can't talk to me anymore. Leah was her best friend. I immediately took out my phone and texted her mom asking if everything was okay. No response. I texted Emily's mom, one of the other girls in her trio. Still nothing. I had just managed to calm my baby girl down when the pizza arrived. Usually our delivery guy is the Apator 5,000. But tonight he just set the box on my doorstep and practically ran away. George, you forgot your tip, I yelled, waving a 20. He just kept going. The next few days were insane. At my daughter's soccer practice, Helen saw me walking towards her and held her phone to her ear. No one had even called her. Helen, what's going on? She mouth, sorry and walked faster. We used to complain about our husbands together. Parents were whispering and showing each other something on their phones. When I walked by, they'd quickly put them away. By Thursday, my daughter was refusing to go to school. They moved my desk away from everyone else. The Teacher said it was for space reasons, but there's like 10 feet between me and Leah now. I tried to bring her to the hairdresser to cheer her up, but when the woman saw me coming, she closed early. No apology. Just flipped the sign and pulled the blinds. My phone buzzed. It was my landlord. Heard what happened. So sorry, rent can wait this month. This was the same man who charged me a 50 dollar inconvenience fee when I paid rent at 12:00am instead of midnight. Then the birthday party, Emily's sleepover. My daughter found out that everyone was invited except her. She was having such a bad panic attack that I had to call a hospital. Mom, what did I do? Emily is my best friend. Enough was enough. I called the school office. Something is happening to my daughter. She's being systematically excluded and I need answers right now. The counselor called back within an hour, but her voice was off like she was choosing every word carefully. Missus Cal, Hannah, we just wanted to check in about your home environment. Is everything safe? Anyone new spending time around your daughter? What? What are you even asking me? I think it's best if we discuss this in person. Can you come in tomorrow morning? No. You'll tell me right now why my daughter is being tortured. Long pause. The principal will explain everything tomorrow. Beep. She hung up. Then at eleven PM, an email from my Gym membership terminated effective immediately. I've been going there for five years. The owner knew me by name. I was trying to figure out what to do when my daughter crawled into my bed at 2:00am sobbing, Mommy, am I ugly? It took everything in me not to burst into tears. The lunch lady wouldn't look at me today. She just pointed at my tray. I finally caved. On Saturday morning, I found myself walking towards the principal's office while being escorted by a security guard. Other parents there for Saturday sports held their kids against the walls as we passed. One mom literally shielded her son with her body like we were dangerous. In his office, the principal locked the door behind us. The click was so loud in the silence, he walked to the windows and twisted the blinds shut. My daughter grabbed my hand tighter. Please sit down. I'll stand. What is this about? He sat at his desk, fingers hovering over his keyboard, then pulled them back. Mister Griffin, you're scaring me. Missus Callahan. He was looking at his screen, not at me. When did you last speak to your ex husband? Christmas. Why? And you haven't been in contact since then? No communication at all? No. We exchange texts about pickup times maybe once a month. What does this have to do with anything? He turned his monitor slightly, then back like he was debating something. Some information has come to our attention about your Former husband, the parents. What information? What are you talking about? I need to show you something, but I want you to prepare yourself. My legs felt weak. I sat down, pulling my daughter onto my lap. It's from two weeks ago. The parents have been. He paused. I've been very concerned. He finally turned the screen toward me. Local news website. The headline hit me first, then his face, my ex husband's face in a mugshot. Full story on channel link below.

Tell my fake boyfriend that I want him to be real. It started at Thanksgiving when my cousin wouldn't shut up about me being single. She kept asking why I never brought anyone home, making these fake concerned faces at the dinner table. So when she said I must be dating someone special, I just nodded, gave him a name right on the spot. Daniel said he was busy with work. My family ate it up. But then Christmas rolled around and my mom started asking when she could meet Daniel. My aunt kept texting about setting an extra place at dinner. I was stuck. That's when my roommate Becca suggested her co worker Daniel, who owed her big time for covering his shifts. He showed me his Instagram, tall brown hair, actually decent looking. He agreed to one dinner as a favor. The problem, he didn't just show up and fake smile through dinner. He brought flowers for my mom, asked my dad about his woodworking hobby and somehow knew my grandmother collected vintage tea cups because I'd mentioned it once when building the fake story. He even laughed at my little brother's terrible jokes about robots. My family was obsessed. After that first dinner, my mom kept inviting him back. Mr brunch, my cousin's graduation party, random Sunday dinners. Daniel never said no. He text me beforehand asking what to bring, if anyone had allergies, stuff like that. He started sending my brother updates about basketball scores, my Dad asked him to help fix our back porch. The worst part was how natural it felt. We drive to my parents house together and he'd ask about my day like we actually dated. He remembered my coffee order, knew I hated mushrooms, grab my jacket when I got cold. During family game night, he'd automatically pick me as his partner. We had inside jokes that weren't even planned. One night after my aunt's birthday party, we sat in his car outside my apartment in complete silence. Everyone had spent the whole night saying how perfect we looked together, how lucky I was. My grandmother even pulled me aside to say Daniel was a keeper. The whole car ride home, I kept stealing glances at him, wondering what he was thinking. I started rehearsing speeches in my bathroom mirror, practice bringing it up casually over coffee. But every time I opened my mouth, nothing came out. How do you tell someone you caught feelings for a fake relationship? Everything changed at Christmas dinner. My aunt announced she'd been looking at wedding venues for us, said she found the perfect place for next fall. Daniel laughed it off perfectly, made some joke about her getting ahead of herself. But later that night, he texted me, we can't keep this up forever, you know, that message hit me like a truck. I realised he was ready to end this whole thing and I wasn't, not even close. Instead of texting back or Giving him some weird speech. I invited him over for dinner at my place, cooked his favourite pasta dish, the one my mom always made when he came over, set the table with actual candles, not just the overhead light. After we finished eating, I was washing dishes and he was drying them, just like we did at my parents house. That's when I finally said it. I know this.

I put a dead man switch in the company workflow as I was getting bullied into quitting. Nobody likes a lunch thief and I had one of the most aggressive at my office. There were rumors for a few months leading up to the inciting incident of someone going around and taking people's lunches. Just about every day someone different would complain that their lunch was missing. It even happened to me once or twice. But I figured, hey, it's a big office. A few people are probably just careless and grab the wrong lunch and are too embarrassed to bring it back. Or someone else packs their lunch and they don't know what's in there so it's not obvious they have the wrong one or whatever. Most people just brought brown bags with their names on it anyways or identical rubber made Tupperware with a little piece of label tape on the side. It was easy enough to mix it up. I had accidentally grabbed the wrong lunch once or twice, but I'd noticed before I got it open. I thought I was just more careful or even just not as busy as some other people in the building. However, other people weren't as forgiving and a quorum made complaints to HR. They were blown off. Personally at the time I thought it was all much ado about nothing. But then it began. My wife enrolled in a French cooking class online and just about every day I was Bringing fancy gourmet leftovers in for lunch, you'd think I was picking up a to go bag from a Michelin starred bistro on the way in. Each morning, she really threw herself into the coursework. There were no problems for about two weeks, maybe three, until one day my lunch went missing. Considering what delicacies I had to look forward to, I was pretty miffed. But I did it once over around the break room and didn't see anyone eating my lunch. So figured someone grabbed my bag by accident earlier, saw how good things looked and realizing it was their lucky day, didn't bring it back to the fridge. I wrote the mysterious stranger off as an asshole, but accepted the loss and looked forward to dinner that night instead. Next day, I write my name on my lunch in extra bold lettering, jam the bag into the back of the fridge and feel peace of mind. I get there come break time, nope, it's gone. I was pretty upset, but I figured it was a stroke of bad luck and left it at that. What else could I do? However, on the third day, out of an abundance of caution, I kept my lunch at my desk. A pain because I had to eat it fairly early in the day to avoid spoilage, but at least I'd know where it was. I got up to take care of some business down the hall and when I came back, Yep, my lunch was gone. Unfortunately, that didn't help me narrow it down much at all because my desk is centrally located, so everyone's constantly passing by. At that point, there was no possibility of the theft being arbitrary. So I approached HR and filed a complaint. Their response, practically verbatim was employees lunches are their personal property and the company is not responsible for lost or stolen personal item.

What's the worst, I hate to break it to you, moment you had with someone? 1. I had an employee who was a strict vegetarian for religious reasons. One day we were discussing the employee salad bar and he mentioned how much he loved the Caesar dressing packets they offered. I was surprised and stupidly blurted out, oh, I didn't realize you ate fish. He responded that he was vegetarian and gave me a quizzical look. I had to explain that the salad dressing contained both fish and Parmesan cheese, which is almost always cultured with animal rennet. He didn't believe me and the next day insisted on reading the ingredients on one of the packets to me to prove to me that I was wrong. Then he got to the anchovies and got quiet, too. My best friend in high school was humongous and would sweat profusely. We would come in after lunch in Texas and he would smell awful. I think he would wear his clothes without washing them after sweating. We had English after and the AC sucked, so the teacher put a fan in the window. He would sit in front of the fan and blow his funk over everyone. The class got together and voted that I should be the one to tell him. Well, I had to break it to him that for the last year, he has smelled horribly. I felt pretty bad, but he never stunk again. 3. I had to tell My friend that the online girlfriend he'd been talking to for months was actually a scammer using stolen photos. He was planning to send her money to come visit. And breaking the news to him was one of the toughest conversations I've ever had. 4. I had a friend ask me about some green sign in the distance. It was in fact a bright orange sign giving off an intense orange light, which sodium vapor is known for. I had to tell him right there that he was colorblind. He was in his mid 30s too. A lot of odd things that had happened in his past fell into place for him that day. Five, I had to tell my mom that my grandma, her mom didn't make it and had been buried a month before. My mom had been in a coma for around six weeks during that time. At one point they were actually in the ICU in beds beside each other. Neither ever knew. So yeah, that sucked. 6. I had an old friend that I lived with at the time. He'd been getting obviously catfished for years, thankfully not monetarily. Just a lonely girl looking for attention over the phone and internet. But he just refused to believe the signs. He claimed to have talked a bunch on the phone and we didn't really believe him. Eventually she asked for money for a ticket and we were all like, there it is. And he finally believed Us. He decided to put it to a test to prove it once and for all and told her that he'd bought her a ticket for the flight, assuming she'd make up an excuse to get out of it. He didn't really buy the ticket. Well, to his surprise, the day of, he got a call from her at the airport panicking because they couldn't find the ticket. He managed to play it off as a mistake and was able to get her on the flight. They dated for 5 years and she came out every summer for like 5 years before they grew apart. So guess I was wrong. Seven, I hate to break it to you, but the hardest moment was telling my best friend that their partner was for the streets. They were so in love and completely blinded by it. And when I broke the news, it shattered their world. It even strained our friendship for a while because sometimes even when you're trying to help, the truth is too painful to accept. 8, an employee confided in me that she contracted the clap and was talking about how she got it from the toilet seat at work because she is monogamous with her husband. I was like, girl, he ain't monogamous with you. 9, my wife telling me that she wants a divorce about 30 minutes ago. I sure hope that I will be okay. Later, it struck me like lightning. 10 when my ex Tried to make me choose between my dog and him.

What part of military culture would surprise non military folk? One, how 24 hour it is. Nobody even blinks when you get up at 3:00am to meet a flight or make a deployment muster. Half the people you know are asleep at three PM their duty next week will probably be different. So you meet friends for cards or a meal at 6:00am or six PM doesn't really matter. Also the different food you eat. After a couple of decades of chow line food, Pan Global, Military Wife Pot locks and TDY and Turd World dumps, you don't even care if you have never seen that dish before in your life or if it's squirming. If the guy next to you isn't deceased, you will probably eat it too. Never leave your Tabasco bottle at home so you can get the bugs too. How non military life on a submarine is. It's already a stressful environment so nobody really wants to pile on top of that. Don't get me wrong, they do their jobs and they do them well. But this straight laced military bearing you see in movies is not really there. My command had to gently remind enlisted types not to refer to the junior officers by their first names. Under way, shaving daily was a luxury. So everyone had some sort of stubble, hair got too long, uniforms, coveralls got torn, stained and just generally jacked up, especially if you worked in the engine room. We all Wore civilian sneakers or slip ons as Navy boots made way too much noise. All that said, if there was a real or simulated emergency, everyone immediately shifted to 100% by the book. Those were some of the finest, most prepared people I've ever worked with. So if you want to see real life on a submarine, watch down. Periscope 3. I found that the idea of a chain of command really messes with the heads of those who never served in the military. 4, dependapotamus. It's something I Learned about a few years ago. Basically, the young guys are desperate to get better housing, so they get married to women who prey on young military men because they get good benefits, health, pension. The women are dependents. The potomus comes from the idea that most of them end up getting gluttonous and slothful, mooching off of their husbands who are away at war and get rather large. It's sad.

What is your, this person has no idea how the real world works. Moment one the other day my 18 year old brother in law got married to his high school sweetheart in a parking garage so that they can live off campus at college together. His now wife's mother is an ordained minister. His parents, my in laws were very upset and he couldn't understand why saying it's just a fake marriage for school. Oh no, sweet boy, you are married. I just laughed and laughed. I love him dearly but he's a moron. His wife lost her scholarship because they live off campus and became residents of the state and she no longer qualifies. 2. My dad used to be the typical boomer, always thinking I was just being lazy and not doing things right until he got injured and could no longer work in an industry he had 30+ years of experience and seniority in. It took him several months to get a new job of any kind and was shocked when he realized that he couldn't just negotiate for higher pay. He was fired on the spot when he threatened to organize a strike and was barred from the premises. When he had to move, it baffled him that he couldn't just give the landlord a few hundred bucks and move in right away but had to wait a week for his application to go through and the landlord to do a background check. Probably my Most satisfying one was when he finally decided to get into the industry. I'm in truck driving. He Learned very fast that it wasn't like it is in the movies from the 80s. Truckers don't know nor ever have given a darn about one another. Sure, some are nice to one another, but if it's a choice of you or them, don't hold your breath. Most big trucking companies in the US are only concerned about your safety because it saves them money on lawsuits. After his third trucking job ended with him getting terminated and is now living off my income, he stopped giving me crap about my problems and is still job hunting. 3. There was a young girl I used to work with a target. She was hired for the 6:00am to two thirty PM shift, but she regularly showed up between 8 to 9:00am without any good explanation. After the third time or so, our supervisor asked her if she had something to do in the morning such as getting kids ready for school that required a later shift. If so, she could be moved to the 8:00am to four thirty PM shift. Girl's response was no, I still want to leave at 2:30. I just don't want to get up that early. She was fired when she refused to acknowledge that you cannot make your own schedule. 4. My boss told me about a friend of his who told him they have a life hack She would get her bills in the mail, not pay them, and then wait a couple of months to pay. Then she would cry so the debt collectors would feel bad and waive the fees for not paying on time. That was her brilliant life. Hack. 5, a dude 18 years old in boot camp got a letter from home and I could see he was agitated being 22 and concerned for his well being. I asked him if he wanted to talk about it. I'm thinking a Dear John letter or the mom and dad divorcing letter. He told me that his younger brother got a Mercedes for his birthday and that he was upset because he only got a BMW. Can't remember what I said, but I knew boot camp was gonna do him in. It did. 6, when I was in boot camp, some kid put his letter addressed to mom with no address attached. 7. They did a study and there's a lot of people who have winning the lottery part of their retirement plan. 8. My old roommate was only paying $25 on her credit cards every month, but was putting almost every purchase on them. I felt so bad explaining to her that she was now in credit card debt. 9, girl asks me to do her shift for her. She has a doctor's appointment, okay, on payday, she asked for the money for that shift. Uh, no, it doesn't work that way.

What are you still mad about years later? One, 20 years ago I was standing on my back porch lighting up and talking on the phone. This cop comes out of the forest behind the house soaking wet and covered in MUD. He walked right up into my yard and I asked if he needed help. He told me to get my fat ass back into the house or he'd arrest me. I just stood there as that cop walked through my yard and away to wherever he was going. 2, About 35 years ago when I was a teenager, the house was broken into. Detectives thought I did it as an inside job. My dad had me sit down with them for questioning. After laughing at the accusation, I realized they were serious and told them no and clammed up. After I asked why my dad would put me in front of them with no warning that I was a suspect, like did he think it was me? He said, I think it could have been you. I never did anything illegal like that in my life. For him to think that definitely rocked my relationship with him. Three thirty seven years ago, I was five and had spent two years saving up $10 worth of pennies. I used to count them, 10 pennies in a pile. Ten piles is $1. I kept them in an empty coffee ground can. One day the jar was empty and we had Pizza for dinner. She made me thank her boyfriend for the pizza. 4. I was kicked out of a bar spelling B for spelling a word correctly. The word was Lilliputian like from Gulliver's Travels. I spelled it correctly. They had it without the double L. I showed them I was correct and they still wouldn't let me back in the spelling bee. This was like five years ago. I'm still super bitter. 5. In my junior year of high school, my parents purchased a car for me, but I made all the payments by working 20 hours a week at a local pizzeria. One weekend my mom asked me to take her car 10 minutes into town to the car wash and wash it. I got back about an hour later and my car was gone. They had an offer from someone my dad worked with, so they sold it right out from under me. I never got the money from the sale. 6 during the lockdown, I graduated from college. It was a huge deal. I was the first in my family. They did a zoom ceremony and the presenter accidentally skipped over my name. My family was all watching waiting for them to call my name via live stream and of course the presenter never fucking did. It was just as devastating for them as it was for me. I will never forget my mom saying, I don't understand. Our name should have been there. Our name Ours. I was graduating for us.

Predators who work in retail. What's the saddest thing someone ever returned? One, I used to be a manager for a Disney store. We had a regular old man come in with his wife regularly. Super cute couple. I mean, matching outfits, holding hands, just cute as could be. We used to sell these huge stuffed animals, like ginormous. The couple came in about once a week and would just walk around, laugh and smile, buy things here and there. One night he came in on his own and bought one of these gigantic Mickey's we had. It was $300, I think. He was so excited. He told us all about how he was going to take her out to dinner and it would be sitting there on the bed to surprise her when they got home. Anyway, two days later, he walked back in carrying the gigantic Mickey Mouse plush to return it. He had bought it to surprise her for her 75th birthday. She passed away in her sleep the day before her birthday. He thanked us and said goodbye and that he would not be coming back because our store reminded him too much of his wife. We found out he passed away a week later, was just seven days from the day his wife passed. We found out all the details because one of our employees went to the same church they attended. Two customers regularly come in with large amounts of baby supplies, returns. They Get the wrong gender items or duplicates. An older woman came in with a cartload so I asked about the new baby. She slowly and through tears explained that her only child and grandbaby didn't make it during childbirth. 3. Not a return, but I worked in a jewelry store and the saddest sale we ever had was a labor. The guy had this ring on labor for 12 months but passed in a car accident. His parents came in and picked up the ring so his girlfriend could keep it. I don't think she had any idea he was going to propose. 4, I work at a store in a college town and one night some younger guy was returning a keg barrel only was still half full. I jokingly asked the guy if it was a trash party or something along those lines and he responded with, yeah, it was a party for one of our friends who passed the day of the party. Five, I was working at a large pet store in the tropical fish department. One busy weekend a very well dressed, rather snobby woman came in and bought six baby angel fish, each about the size of a dime plus the fins. The store I worked in was inside a huge high end shopping mall so we had a holding service where we would bag up fish, cash the customer out and float the fish in their bags in a warm tank until the Customer was finished all their shopping and was ready to leave for home. As a matter of course, I offered to hold this lady's baby angel fish. She said she was all good and left. Four or five hours later, she stormed back into the store demanding a manager and a refund. She was shaking the bag in our faces for emphasis, yelling that her gorgeous angels were all deceased. On close inspection, we discovered that the silly woman had put the poor fish in her car, presumably so she didn't need to carry them while she shopped for other things or returned to the store to pick them up. Unfortunately, because it was January and the temperature outside was extremely cold, the tiny babies had frozen. 6. A guy was returning baby formula and he was looking pretty down. I asked him how his day was and he said that he has been having a long day and that he's been having a long month too. I thought he just had a baby, so maybe he just got the wrong formula. I asked if he just had a baby and he said he used to have a baby. I told him I was sorry and he said it was okay. There were a few minutes of silence and he said he was a fun little guy, seen a lot of things, but that one broke my heart.

What is the most inoffensive thing you've seen someone get offended by? One maybe 22 years ago, I had a phone interview with a baking company. I didn't care to have my peers know what I was up to, so I took the call on my cell phone in my car. The call was crystal clear and no technical issues. At one point, they had mentioned the weather and asked how it was where I was. I told him that I was sitting in my car and I could see that it was actively snowing and what not. The interviewer asked me, are you taking this call on a cell phone? I told him I was. Then he asked me if I thought that was appropriate. I asked him what he meant by that. He said he thought it was kind of rude to take a formal call on a cell phone. I told him I would be more than happy to conclude the interview if talking on a cell phone was an issue. If he was interested, I'd be happy to continue it the next day when I'd be at a desk. He again repeated how rude he thought it was that I had called from a cell phone and that there was no need to continue the interview process. I disagreed with the first point, but did agree with the second. To this day, I wonder what in the world he was talking about and where he was. Coming from too. At my wedding we marked the vegetarian items as vegetarian. This made the one vegetarian in my wedding sister in law who hates me fly into a catatonic rage because we are singling out the vegetarian food as vegetarian and not treating it as normal food. Then how the heck are they supposed to know it's vegetarian? Guess she wanted to be able to ask so then everybody knows they're vegetarian lol. Three. I once listened to my boss try to lecture the fire marshal because he was talking about something being flame retardant. Her reasoning was you should just call it fireproof because retardant was an awful word. It was one of those times where I really should have tried to stop her, but instead I just stood off to the side making a surprise Pikachu face. Four. This guy at a Halloween party I was at was dressed in a giant bacon costume. Some girl was yelling at him for being so offensive toward those who didn't eat bacon. For various reasons. Mind you, she ate pork. One of the guys who didn't eat bacon at the party asked her what the heck she was talking about, but she didn't back down. Lol. I have no idea why people feel they need to go out of their way to be inaccurately offended on behalf of other people. 5. One time someone got offended when I put on my seatbelt. She thought I was commenting on Her ability to drive. The same thing happened to me when inside a taxi, he asked, do you wear your seatbelt when you're with your dad? I said, yes. Six. My seven month old was wearing a shirt that had a rocket ship and the NASA logo. And some middle aged woman in the shop said he shouldn't be wearing that because he's clearly not an astronaut. I was dumbfounded. 7 at school, someone didn't have a calculator and asked if anyone had one they could borrow. Someone offered them a pink calculator and they refused, saying that they were offended. They try and give them something less masculine. Clearly they didn't need a calculator that badly if they're just gonna whine about the color. Eight. I'm a nurse at a children's hospital. I was wearing Mickey Mouse Halloween scrubs, which have little dancing skeletons on it. A visitor for one of my patients complained that I was wearing scary and inappropriate scrubs. Nine. People get very offended that I don't like being touched, and this happened just last week. I work at a bank in an affluent part of Atlanta, and a woman called in to let us know she was offended by the security questions for her online banking. The security questions she set up herself. 11. Wearing a mask in public.

I watched so much TikTok, it ended up saving a life. My first few months as a 9 1 1 operator were scary, but nothing could have prepared me for when I got a call late at night from a young girl. I could barely understand what she was saying through her sobbing, but she told me she had just swallowed an entire bottle of pills and just wanted someone to talk to before they did anything. I started asking her why she would do that and asked for her address. She thought I already had it. But after a few minutes, she finally told me where she lived. She said she was severely depressed and just wanted everything to end. I asked her why, just trying to keep her on the phone and she said she couldn't take the hate she was getting anymore. I knew I only had literal minutes to do something and tried talking her into throwing up. She told me no. So I asked her what kind of hate she was getting. Apparently, she just wanted people to like her and wanted to help people. She was getting a lot of hate comments on TikTok and even people in real life. Then it all clicked. I knew I recognized her voice and I actually knew who she was. After a few minutes, I asked her if she was who I thought and she was really surprised. I started to tell her how one of her Videos actually changed my life and got me out of a toxic relationship. She knew I wasn't lying because I told her all about it. I asked her one more time and she finally agreed to try and make herself throw up. She was unconscious when the paramedics got there, but because of that, she was still alive. She now has millions of followers and I'm glad to see her much happier today.

My son made a kid cry on his birthday and I was so proud of him. When my son was in the third grade, he was a bully. We tried everything, but he kept constantly getting in trouble and sent to the office. He was known throughout the school for tying balloons to the class rabbit and almost letting it float away. I was leaving work to go get him and as my phone rang, I already knew who it was. I had a special ringtone for his teacher because she called me so much just so I could prepare to hear what he did. She was crying when I answered and I knew it was bad. I told her I was on the way, but instead of getting upset, she started to thank me. I was really confused and she started to talk about what a sweet boy I raised. Literally nobody had ever told me that before for. And I asked what happened. Apparently another kid who didn't have a lot of friends was in his class and his mom had handed out birthday invitations to everyone the day before. Right before the bell went off, he stood up in front of everyone and asked who was coming to his party. The entire class was now silent and he just stood there looking around for someone to tell him they were going. Nobody was saying anything. And she said she could see the kids heart literally breaking in Real time. Then, as he went to sit back down in shame, my son stood up and said, I'm gonna come. I'll be there. His face lit up, and one by one, all the other boys in the class followed his lead and also started telling him they'd come, too. He was trying not to cry when we showed up that weekend.

People who got expelled from school. What did you do in 9th grade? I got the teacher everybody wanted for biology. Except one morning our entire class could hear her outside the room getting chewed out by our assistant principal for being late on grading. We also knew she had lost her sister the week before, so she was having a really rough time. A few minutes into teaching, she started explaining something about our final exam and the guys next to me were passing notes. They usually did it every time she turned around, but this time she saw them. She usually wouldn't have cared, but she thought it was something about her. So she walked over and asked to see it. Kid shook his head without saying anything. So she basically reached into his pocket to grab the note. She started reading it in front of the class and said, I left it in the garbage bin in room W12. It's all there with the. And stopped herself before reading the rest out loud. She looked down at the boy, clearly having read something bad and didn't know what to say. Her face was pale and not knowing what to do. She grabbed them both and literally yanked them out of the room. We all sat there confused for a half hour wondering what that note said. There were police at our school and they asked our whole route to come to the office. They questioned everybody about It, but nobody knew anything. And by the time they let us go, they had sent everybody home. We later found out that the note said there was a key to the office in that garbage bin along with a loaded gun. Both of them denied writing it and said they didn't know who it was for. So they decided to fire our teacher for creating a school wide panic and expelled our entire row.

What was the most illegal thing that happened at your school? A few students decided to play a senior prank on the principal by writing on his car. And it made him so mad he decided to cancel the entire prom for the year. Everyone was pissed. So at the homecoming game the week after, we were chanting to bring it back. Eventually at the end, some kid with a banana suit jumped over the bleachers and ran across the field. Everyone screamed as he was being chased by coaches and teachers, and even the players loved it. Eventually, they tackled him hard and he ended up breaking his arm and had to go to the hospital. They had to cancel the game and the staff were so mad they suspended him for the rest of the year. He was probably gonna get expelled, but the students loved him so much, they decided they were gonna do something about it. That day, free Banana Man was born and everyone started chanting it in the halls. Few guys sold t shirts that said it and they wrote it all over the walls. At our school, there were bananas everywhere. And this made our principal so mad, he banned the phrase entirely. However, he didn't just stop there. He decided to go as far as to ban the actual fruit itself and even the entire color yellow. You literally weren't allowed to wear yellow to school. And if you were caught eating A banana, you were sent home for the day. This rule made the entire student body so furious they pretty much declared a war on the administration. Hundreds of students were getting sent home because they decided to bring bananas and wear yellow. And when they tell them to take their yellow shirts off, they'd walk around shirtless to class. I even saw a guy come to school in all yellow, and when they made him take it off, he tried to go to class only in his underwear, which was also yellow. It got so crazy that one kid who literally needed to eat bananas for the potassium couldn't for the week and ended up passing out in the middle of class. He went to the hospital and his parents threatened to sue the school. The very next day, we watched our principal walk out for the last time and the banana guy returned wearing his costume.

Back in middle school, me and my friends actually made our own secret language to pass notes. At first, we tried writing backwards so if teachers or classmates tried to peek, they couldn't read it quickly. But then we realized if our notebooks ever got confiscated, it would still be easy to figure out. So we went full spy mode. We created a whole alphabet, gave each letter its own symbol, and memorized it. Suddenly, we could write full conversations in class, and no one had a clue what we were saying. Bye, high school. We didn't really use it anymore, but I still had all the symbols memorized. One day, I was in class journaling about a crush in the back of my notebook. I wasn't disrupting anyone, but my teacher noticed how into it I was and decided to call me out. He goes, what, are you writing a book over there? Clearly those aren't notes. I froze, snapped the notebook shut immediately. Thankfully, he just made a little joke and moved on. But there was no way I was about to risk my thoughts about this girl being read out loud to the whole class. So the next time I journaled, I switched back. Back to the secret language. To everyone else, it looked like I was just doodling random symbols, but to me, it was the perfect cover. Fast forward. Years later, I find those old notebooks again. And the problem. I had thrown away the Only translator we ever made. Which means all the secrets I wrote as a kid are now locked away forever. In a language even I don't understand anymore. Guys, what do I do?

Do you guys ever get that heavy feeling when you realise you're not really a priority to anyone? Like, I feel like I only exist when my friends are bored, lonely or need something from me. Whenever I need them, I'm left on delivered for hours, sometimes all day. It's like I'm just a second option or a last option. And honestly, sometimes I'm not even an option at all. They never prioritize me. They never make time unless it's convenient for them. And the worst part, I still show up for them. Every single time.

Bro, nothing cracks me up more than the sorry for the late reply text. Like late. That wasn't late. That was a whole ghosting session. You disappeared for 24 hours like you were filming an episode of survivor and then they pop back like, oops, I was busy, busy with what? A NASA mission. You didn't just reply late. You respond after a whole day cycle. Honestly, don't say late reply. Just admit you didn't feel like texting me back. Be real because if I vanish for 24 hours, trust people are filing a missing person's report.

Why the hell are 45 minute classes treated like a prison sentence? Like, bro, 45 minutes doesn't sound bad until you're sitting there watching the clock tick slower than your Wi-Fi when it's buffering. And then on top of that, zero recess. None. Like, sorry, when did we sign up for corporate America? At age 15, you expect me to sit through seven classes straight? No break, no sunlight, just pure fluorescent lighting and trauma? By third period, my brain's gone, my soul's gone, and my will to live is on the attendance sheet marked absent. At this point, recess isn't a luxury, it's a human right.
NA

Bro, when my parents say we need to talk, I mentally start planning my fucking funeral. Like, why you gotta say it like that? Just say what it's about. Give me a hint, a theme, a fucking trailer. The second I hear we need to talk, my brain's like, that's it. They found out everything. Even the shit I didn't do yet. I'm sweating, I'm pacing. I'm suddenly remembering lies I told four years ago. I'm like, was it the grades, the charger I stole in 2019? That one time I said, okay with attitude, bro, I'm sitting on the couch like I'm waiting for a death sentence. Then they finally say, you've been leaving dishes in the sink. Like, why the fuck you build it up? Like I just committed war crimes.

Why is there always that one person who's never seen without a vape? Like bro, do you even breathe air? They hit that thing like it's their life support. One puff every five seconds. You'll be mid conversation and suddenly cloud of blueberry vanilla Ice Blast hits your face like a smoke machine at a concert. And it's always the wildest flavors too. Dragon blood watermelon cotton candy explosion or some nonsense. I'm like bro, that's not a snack, that's battery powered diabetes. And what kills me is they always say I'm not addicted though, while their vape is literally on a lanyard like a damn necklace. Take one deep breath without it. I dare you. Their lungs probably smell like a Yankee Candle store at this point. They don't even exhale, they just exist in mist.
NA

I don't know how to explain it, but I really love people who make sure I don't feel left out. Like, it's the little things, when they slide me into the conversation or when they make sure I'm included in the plans. It just means so much. It makes you feel like you actually matter to them. And that feeling, that's something I'll never take for granted. Well, anyways, thanks. Out. Mwah.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.
NA
NA

Why is getting the message, can we talk, the scariest thing in history? Like, bro, those three words will instantly ruin your whole day. It doesn't matter if you're chilling, eating or having the best time of your life. As soon as you see can we talk, your stomach drops, your brain starts running every crime you might have committed since birth. And the worst part, they never explain right away. You're just left staring at your phone like it's a ticking time bomb. Bro, if it's important, say it. If it's not, don't traumatize me with the most terrifying text in existence.

Bro, why do people actually act like math is the hardest thing in the world? Like, yeah, it looks scary when you see a bunch of numbers and letters chilling together, but once you break it down, it's literally just patterns and rules on repeat. Half the time people aren't even struggling with the math. They're struggling with the panic they built up in their head. Like the second they see X, their brain clocks out like it's some alien language. Bro. It's not rocket science. It's just step by step puzzles. Math isn't hard. What's hard is convincing yourself to stop saying it's impossible before you even try.

So Charlie Craig just died. Look, I never looked up to the guy or idolized him, but people celebrating his death isn't cool at all for any reason. And whatever he did is in the past. Yeah, he could have been a rapist or whatever, but being happy because someone died isn't cool at all. I know for sure there will be a couple of haters, but it's alright. I don't care. But like, just imagine one day Charlie's kids go on social media to see what happened to his dad and they start seeing all the videos and comments people are saying about him. He might have not been the best person in the world, but at least he had passion for his speeches and look like a great father. He might have done fucked up shit, but that's normal. I fucked up too. And I'm still here because y'all wanted me to be here. And if you don't got anything nice to say, just don't say it. Imagine Charlie was your dad and you start seeing people being happy about his death anyways, may Charlie Crick rest in peace.

You know what? I love people who don't make me feel like an option. Like it feels so different when someone actually chooses you, you know, not just when they're bored or when it's easy, but because they really want you there. It shows in the little things, when they check in, when they make time, when they make you feel like you actually matter. And that feeling, that's the kind of thing that sticks with you. Well, anyways, VEX out. Mwah.
NA
NA

I poured my husband's sweet tea down the drain. So my husband Jake has this obsession with sweet tea. Not just any sweet tea, his grandmother's recipe that he makes every single Sunday in this massive gallon pitcher. He uses like 2 cups of sugar, which is disgusting if you ask me. But whatever. The man drinks it all week long and god forbid anyone else touches it. I'm talking about a grown man who literally wrote his name on the picture with a Sharpie. Now, here's where it gets weird. Jake works construction and every morning he fills up this be up old thermos with his precious tea. But here's the thing, he never actually drinks it at work, never. He just carries it around like some kind of security blanket, brings home still full every single day. I thought this was just some quirky habit until last Tuesday when I was doing laundry and found his work shirt absolutely reeking of alcohol. Not beer smell, not wine, straight up vodka. And this wasn't the first time. I've been finding these shirts for weeks. But I kept making excuses. Maybe someone spilled something on him. Maybe he walked past a bar. Stupid stuff like that. So Wednesday morning, I decided to follow him to work. I know how that sounds, but I had to know what was going on. I parked across the street from his job site and watched him for like 20 minutes. The guy pulls out. His thermos unscrews the top, pours out all the sweet tea onto the ground, and then pulls out a bottle of vodka from his lunch box and fills the whole thing up. I sat there in my car just staring. My husband of eight years was day drinking at work. You sing his grandmother's sweet tea recipe as a cover story. The same man who lectured me about having a glass of wine with dinner because someone needs to be responsible in this house. But wait, it gets worse. That night at dinner, he's going on and on about how hard work was, how his back hurts, how his boss is being unreasonable. Meanwhile, I'm looking at him knowing he spent the day sipping vodka out of a thermos while operating heavy machinery. The guy was literally putting people's lives at risk. I didn't say anything that night because I was still processing it. But Thursday morning, same thing. Friday, same thing. By this point, I'm wondering how long this has been going on and how I never noticed. Then I remembered all those times he came home exhausted and went straight to bed at like seven PM all those weekends he was too tired to do any. The man wasn't tired. He was hungover. Sunday comes around and here he is making his weekly batch of sweet tea, humming to himself like nothing's wrong. He's going on about how his grandmother would be so proud that he kept the Tradition alive, how it's the one thing that gets him through the work week. I'm standing there watching him stir in cup after cup of sugar, knowing full well that this, he is just going to end up on the ground while he fills that thermos with vodka. That's when I snapped. The second he went upstairs to shower, I grabbed that pitcher and poured every last drop down the kitchen.

Bro, we all got that one friend who knows literally everyone. Like why is it that everywhere I go with you turns into a full blown family reunion? I can't even walk in peace. Every two seconds you're like, yo, bro, long time no see. Like, huh? Who even is bro? We could be at an airport in a different country and you're dapping up half the flight crew like y'all shared bunk beds in kindergarten. And don't even get me started on the grocery store. I'm just trying to buy Doritos. And now you're over here catching up with your cousin's boyfriend's barber's sister's dog trainer. Craziest part, you remember every single detail. Oh yeah, he used to play soccer with me back in year 5. Then he moved to North Korea, came back and his brother married my other friend's teacher's booty inspector. Like, what are you even saying right now? And it's suspicious too, cause I've never actually seen them meet anyone new. Like bro just spawns connections out of thin air. Meanwhile, my brain can't even remember my Netflix password and you out here with more connections than Wi-Fi.

My school starts in just one week, and honestly, I'm not ready. Not because I don't wanna go, but because I haven't bought anything yet. And the truth is, I can't afford it. I'm supposed to be excited about a new school year, but instead I'm stressed. I need braces, but I can't afford them. I want skincare, maybe a little makeup, just something to feel confident, to feel pretty walking into school. But right now I don't have that. That's why my goal is to hit 10 K followers before school starts. Because maybe, just maybe, this can be the start of something for me, something I can do for myself. So if you're watching this, even if you don't know what to say, just comment something, even random dots. It still helps more than you think. And please don't forget to follow. Every little bit of support means the world to me right now.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favourite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

How did you use an UNO reverse to turn your family's rules upside down? Every Sunday for 15 years, my grandmother made the same announcement at family dinner. When I pass away, everything goes to whoever visits me most. She tap her cane on the floor and smile like she just revealed state secrets. This turned my entire extended family into vultures. My Aunt Rachel drove three hours every Tuesday I just to vacuum Grandma's living room. Uncle Steve called twice daily asking about her arthritis. My cousin Jennifer moved back from California and started doing Grandma's grocery shopping. They all hated each other but pretended to be saints around her. Meanwhile, I was banned from inheritance discussions. I liked guys chicken nuggets and grandma made it crystal clear that sinners don't deserve family money. She changed the subject. Whenever I entered rooms, my cousins would smirk and whisper about how I'd be working at McDonald's while they lived in luxury. But here's what none of them knew. I actually loved spending time with grandma. Not for money, she'd already told me I wasn't getting any, but because she was genuinely funny. When she wasn't performing for the Inheritance Hunters, while they argued over who deserved what, I'd sneak over on Wednesday nights to watch old movies and eat ice cream. Grandma would relax completely. When it was just us, she'd tell dinosaurs jokes from the two thousand BC and complain about how fake everyone was being. She even started Asking about my boyfriend and seemed genuinely interested in our relationship. I never mentioned these visits to anyone because I knew they'd think I was gaming. After she passed last year, the whole family gathered for the will reading. Rachel brought a calculator. Steve wore his funeral suit from 1995. Jennifer had already started planning her European vacation. They were practically drooling as the lawyer opened the envelope.

Does anyone else think it's suspicious when your boyfriend suddenly starts working out after years of being lazy? My boyfriend Jake had been the same couch potato for three years. The guy who needed me to open pickle jars was suddenly doing push UPS at 6:00am. When I asked what sparked this change, he just shrugged and said he wanted to get healthy, but something felt wrong. It start started small. He bought protein powder and left it on the kitchen counter like some kind of trophy. Then he got a gym membership to this fancy place across town instead of the Planet Fitness two blocks away. When I suggested we work out together, he got weird and said he preferred going alone to focus. The red flags kept piling up. He started showering immediately after coming home from the gym, which seemed normal until I realized he never smelled like sweat. His gym clothes were always perfectly clean, too. One day I decided to surprise him with lunch at his gym. The guy at the front desk looked confused when I asked for Jake. Turns out he hadn't been there in weeks. I confronted him that night. He got defensive and said he switched gyms because the other one was too crowded. When I asked which gym, he stuttered and said some random name I'd never heard of. That's when I knew he was lying. So I did what any suspicious girlfriend would do. I followed him the next Tuesday I watched him drive past three different gyms and pull into the parking lot of a Starbucks. Through the window I saw him sitting across from this blonde girl who definitely wasn't just a workout buddy. She was laughing at everything he said and touching his arm constantly. My heart was pounding as I watched them for 20 minutes. When she got up to leave, he grabbed her hand and kissed it. I wanted to storm in there and cause a scene, but instead I waited. He came home an hour later with this fake exhausted look, complaining about how intense his workout was. I played along for two more weeks, watching him lie to my face every single day. He even started buying workout supplements and leaving them around the apartment as props. The worst part was when he'd flex his non existent new muscles and ask if I noticed any changes and I got clever. I told him my friend Emma was looking for a new gym and asked for his recommendation. He panicked and said his gym was full and not taking new members. When I offered to call and check, he quickly said they had a waiting list and it wouldn't be worth it. That weekend Jake said he was going to a special Saturday morning workout class. Instead, I followed him to the same Starbucks. This time they were holding hands across the table and looking at something on her phone together when he Leaned over and kissed her forehead. I knew I had enough evidence, but I didn't confront him yet. I had a better plan. I went home and researched the girl on social media. Found her Instagram through the Starbucks location tag. Her name was Ashley, and according to her posts, she'd been seeing someone new for the past month. The timeline matched perfectly with Jake's and fitness obsession. Monday night, I casually mentioned

Awkward favor someone has ever called in. My phone buzzed at 2:00am with a text that made me sit straight up in bed. Remember that favor you owe me? I need you to be my boyfriend at my sister's wedding this Saturday. Pick me up at four PM wear navy. It was from Poppy, the girl who saved my entire college career three years ago. I hadn't spoken to her since graduation when I drunkenly promised her anything, anytime, after she spent an entire semester tutoring me through chemistry for free. Without her, I would have lost my scholarship and dropped out. Now she was calling in that favor and honestly, being someone's fake boyfriend for a day seemed like a small price to pay. Plus, if I was being honest with myself, I'd always wondered what it would have been like to actually date. When I picked her up that Saturday, Poppy answered the door looking absolutely stunning in an emerald dress that made her green eyes even brighter. But her expression was all business. She handed me a typed sheet of paper titled Our Relationship Details with bullet points about our first date, how long we've been together and my supposed favourite things about her. Eight months, she said, adjusting my tie without making eye contact. We've been dating eight months. You call me pop sometimes. We met at a coffee shop. Her voice was mechanical like she was reading a grocery list. During the drive, she explained The situation, my parents keep trying to set me up with their business partner's son at every family event. He's perfectly nice, but I'm just not interested. This will shut them up for a while. The whole ride, she was silent. Then when we arrived at the venue, she took a deep breath, grabbed my hand and suddenly transformed into a completely different person. Ready, babe, she said with a bright smile that didn't quite reach her eyes. The ceremony was beautiful. I caught Poppy wiping her eyes during the vows and without thinking, I handed her my pocket square. She looked surprised but took it, whispering thanks so quietly, I almost missed it. During the reception, I found myself forgetting this was an act. When her uncle made a toast, I instinctively put my arm around her shoulders. When the music was too loud to hear her cousin's story, I leaned down so she could whisper it in my ear, her breath warm against my neck. Her grandmother cornered us by the dessert table, pinching my cheeks and telling Poppy in a stage whisper, this one's much better than Adrian. Poppy went rigid at the name, but I squeezed her hand and smoothly changed the subject to Grandma's famous apple pie recipe. The couple's dance was when everything shifted. Poppy was stiff in my arms, counting steps under her breath like she was solving an equation. Hey, I whispered, pulling her closer. Just follow me. Stop thinking so hard. She looked up at me and for a moment, her guard completely dropped. She melted into me, her head finding that perfect spot against my shoulder. We swayed together as the song played and I found myself hoping it would never end. Then during the bouquet toss, she caught it by accident when it bounced off another girl's hands, the crowd cheered, but Poppy immediately handed it to the girl beside her, laughing it off. Just superstition anyway, she said. But I noticed her looking at the flowers longingly as the other girl walked away. Her sister pulled me aside while Poppy was in the bathroom. Thank you, she said, squeezing my arm for making her happy, if it's just for tonight. The words stuck with me. As the night wound down, I realized I wasn't acting anymore. When I looked at her laughing with her cousins, I felt a pull in my chest that had nothing to do with owing her a favor, driving her home. I couldn't keep it in anymore. Poppy, I know this was just repaying a debt, but tonight felt real to me, really real. She went completely still in the passenger seat when I pulled up to her apartment. She practically jumped out of the car. You did great. Perfect. Fake boyfriend. We're even now. The words came out rushed and cold. She was already at her building's door before I could respond. I sat there for five minutes feeling like an idiot before Driving home the next morning, Poppy's sister texted me, you left your.
NA

Daughter dye her hair blue. My sister called me a bad mom until her kid told me the truth. When Emma asked if she could dye her hair blue for her 13th birthday, I said, sure, it's just hair, right? She'd been begging me for weeks, showing me Pinterest photos of these gorgeous ocean blue highlights. Target. We picked out some semi permanent dye that would wash out in a month. She was so excited she could barely sit still while I painted the streaks in our tiny bathroom. The next morning at breakfast, she kept flipping her hair and grinning at herself in the toaster reflection. I made her favourite blueberry pancakes and she kept saying how the blue and her hair match the berries perfectly. honestly the happiest I'd seen her since her dad moved out last year. But when we showed up at my sister Beth's house for Sunday dinner, everything went sideways fast. Beth took one look at Emma and her face just dropped. She pulled me into the kitchen while Emma was playing with her cousins and started going off about how irresponsible I was being. What kind of message does this send, she whispered harshly, gesturing toward the living room. She's going to look like some delinquent at school. I tried explaining it was just temporary hair dye, that Emma was still getting straight A's and playing violin. But Beth wouldn't hear it. She kept shaking her head and muttering about how I was clearly struggling as a single mom and needed to set better boundaries. The whole dinner was awkward after that with Beth making passive aggressive comments about certain parenting choices every time Emma's hair caught the light. When we got home that night, Emma seemed deflated. She kept touching her hair and asking if I thought it looked stupid. I reassured her it looked amazing, but I could tell Beth's reaction had gotten to her. That's when I decided to call my mom to vent about the whole thing. Mom listened patiently while I ranted about Beth being judgmental. Then she got quiet for a moment. Honey, she said carefully, there's something you should probably know about your sister's situation. Apparently, Beth had been calling.

I didn't go out to eat to celebrate my brother's wedding when I wasn't even invited to his wedding. So my brother Jake got married, like, three weeks ago, and the whole thing was basically a slap in the face. His wife Megan, decided nobody under 21 could come because they were serving alcohol and didn't want any minors getting drunk. I was 19 at the time, which apparently made me some kind of liability. The excuse was complete bullshit, and everyone knew it. I don't even drink that much. Maybe a beer here and there with friends, but I'm not some alcoholic teenager who's gonna embarrass their precious wedding. But whatever. That's what they decided, and my parents just went along with it, like always. I asked them to reconsider a few times because, honestly, it hurt. Jake and I used to be close growing up. Shared a room until I was 14, played video games together, the whole thing. But ever since he started dating Megan two years ago, she's basically been calling all the shots. She thinks she's better than everyone because her dad owns some car dealership and she went to private school. After they kept saying no, I just stopped caring. If I wasn't good enough for their wedding, then fine. I wasn't gonna beg anymore. Then last Saturday rolls around, and Jake, our family group chat, saying he wants everyone to go to some fancy steakhouse to celebrate the wedding. My parents were all Excited, talking about how nice it would be to finally celebrate as a family. But I just replied that I wasn't going. My mom called me right away asking why not? I told her the same thing I told everyone else. I didn't see the point in celebrating something I wasn't even invited to. She tried to guilt trip me, saying it would mean a lot to Jake and that my cousins Becca and Tyler were going even though they didn't get invited either. But here's the thing. Becca is 13 and Tyler is 15. Their parents literally forced them to go. They didn't have a choice. I'm 19, I pay my own phone Bill, I work at Best Buy part time, and I'm starting community college in the fall. I can make my own decisions about where I spend my Saturday night. My parents kept trying to convince me all week. My dad even offered to pay for my meal, which honestly just made it worse. Like, you couldn't fight for me to be at the actual wedding, but now you wanna throw money at me to show up to the Celebration dinner? The night of the dinner, I stayed home and ordered pizza. I was playing call of duty with my friends when my phone started blowing up. First it was Jake texting me asking where I was, and Megan sent me this long paragraph about how disappointed she was that I couldn't be mature enough to support my Brother's happiness. The funniest part is they acted all surprised that I didn't show up. I literally told them I wasn't going. What did they expect? After they got home from dinner, Jake came to my room and tried to have some

Bro, how are there still people out there that don't know how to ride a bike? Like, you're out here doing taxes, applying for jobs, driving cars, but the side of two wheels makes you flinch. Riding a bike is a cannon event in growing up. Like it was an achievement for everybody except for you. And they always say, yeah, I just never really Learned how to. Bro, you had years. What were you doing while the rest of us were outside with scraped knees and helmets too big for our heads? Like, be honest, you can't balance. It's basically walking but with handles. The bike does have to work for you. All you gotta do is not fall over. And don't give me, the bikes were never my thing. Excuse. What does that even mean? Breathing is not my thing either. But here I am doing it every day. I swear, if we ever go on a group ride and you say, I'll meet you there, I better not catch you on a rental e scooter. You trust that wobbly plank with a motor more than a bike? Be serious. You missed out on one of the best childhood feelings, that breeze hitting your face when you're speeding down a hill, feeling like you own the world. Riding a bike isn't just a skill, it's a universal experience. You skipped a childhood achievement. Yeah, but hey, it's not too late to learn. Trust me.
